cards.front: What is the order of the Taylor series error for e^x using k terms?
cards.back: O(x^(k+1)) as x → 0. The leading error term is x^(k+1)/(k+1)!. Adding one more term gains one power of x in the error bound.

cards.front: How do you read convergence order from a log-log plot?
cards.back: The slope m of the log-log plot gives the convergence order: log(error) = log(C) + m·log(x). Slope m = Δ(log error)/Δ(log x).
|f_k − f_{k−1}| < ε. Used because the true value P is unknown. Based on Cauchy sequence theory — if successive terms get close, the sequence converges.
|P − f_{k+1}| ≤ C|P − f_k|^m as k → ∞. m = 1: linear (error multiplied by C). m = 2: quadratic (digits double each step).

cards.front: State the analytic error bound for E_k approximating e^x.
Why does k! eventually dominate |x|^k for any fixed x?
cards.back: k! grows superexponentially (each factor increases by 1), while |x|^k grows at most exponentially (same factor x each time). By Stirling: k! ~ √(2πk)(k/e)^k >> |x|^k.

cards.front: With quadratic convergence, if error is 10⁻³, what is it after 2 more steps?
cards.back: Step 1: ~C·(10⁻³)² = ~10⁻⁶. Step 2: ~C·(10⁻⁶)² = ~10⁻¹². Digits: 3 → 6 → 12. This explosive accuracy gain is why Newton-Raphson is powerful.

cards.front: What is the convergence rate of the Taylor series for e^x?
cards.back: Linear (m = 1). The ratio |ε_{k+1}/ε_k| → |x|/(k+2) ≤ C as k → ∞. Despite being 'linear', the shrinking constant makes practical convergence fast.

cards.front: For e^0.5, how many Taylor terms are needed for 10⁻³ accuracy?
cards.back: 5 terms (k = 5). The MATLAB code converges in 5 iterations with error 2.3×10⁻⁵, well below the 10⁻³ threshold.

cards.front: Why is |x| < 1 especially good for Taylor convergence?
cards.back: Both |x|^k → 0 (numerator shrinks) and 1/k! → 0 (denominator grows), so |x|^k/k! converges superexponentially. At |x| > 1, |x|^k grows initially but k! always wins eventually.
